elements.content: Reduction of the tris­(tert-butylcyclopentadienyl) complexes, Cpt 3Ln (Cpt = C5H4CMe3), with potassium in the presence of 18-crown-6 forms the crystallographically characterizable Ln­(II) complexes, {[K­(18-crown-6)]­[(μ-Cpt)2CeCpt]} n and [K­(18-crown-6)­(THF)2]­[Cpt 3Ln] (Ln = Ce, Gd). EPR data indicate that La­(II) and Y­(II) complexes also form upon reduction of Cpt 3Ln. Single crystals of the mixed-valent complexes, [K­(18-crown-6)]­[(μ-Cpt)­CeCpt 2]2 and [K­(2.2.2-cryptand)]­[Cpt 3Dy]2, have also been isolated as part of this study and structurally characterized.

EPR data indicate that La(II) and Y(II) complexes also form upon reduction of Cpt 3Ln. Single crystals of the mixed-valent complexes, [K(18-crown-6)][(μ-Cpt)CeCpt 2]2 and [K(2.2.2-cryptand)][Cpt 3Dy]2, have also been isolated as part of this study and structurally characterized.

elements.content: The use of silyl-substituted cyclopentadienyl ligands such as C5H4SiMe3 (Cp′) and C5H3(SiMe3)2 (Cp″) has led to important developments in the +2 oxidation state chemistry for both the rare-earth and the actinide metals. These ligands allowed the first isolation and structural characterization of molecular complexes of +2 ions for Y, La, Ce, Pr, Gd, Tb, Ho, Er, and Lu as well as Th, U, Np, and Pu, as shown in .
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The use of silyl-substituted cyclopentadienyl ligands such as C5H4SiMe3 (Cp') and C5H3(SiMe3)2 (Cp") has led to important developments in the +2 oxidation state chemistry for both the rare-earth and the actinide metals. These ligands allowed the first isolation and structural characterization of molecular complexes of +2 ions for Y, La, Ce, Pr, Gd, Tb, Ho, Er, and Lu as well as Th, U, Np, and Pu, as shown in .   1

elements.content: Lappert and co-workers initially showed the importance of employing silyl-substituted cyclopentadienyl ligands by attempting to make alkyl-substituted analogues with C5H3(CMe3)2 (Cptt) ligands. They reported only a transient dark purple solution from the reduction of the alkyl–cyclopentadienyl complex, Cptt 3La, but they found that it was possible to isolate crystallographically characterizable La­(II) complexes from the reduction of the analogous silyl–cyclopentadienyl complex, Cp″3La, according to . This is consistent with previous electrochemical data on (C5R5)2ZrCl2 complexes which showed that the trimethylsilyl-substituted cyclopentadienyl ligands were better able to delocalize the electron density away from the metal than the alkyl-substituted analogues. Although Nd­(II) and Dy­(II) complexes have been isolated with the tris­(tert-butyl)­cyclopentadienyl ligand, C5H2(CMe3)3 (Cpttt), they were isolated as bis­(cyclopentadienyl) metallocenes with a third noncyclopentadienyl ligand: [Cpttt 2Nd­(μ-I)­K­(18-crown-6)]·C6H12 and [Cpttt 2Dy­(μ-X)­K­(18-crown-6)] (X = BH4, Br, I).

This is consistent with previous electrochemical data on (C5R5)2ZrCl2 complexes which showed that the trimethylsilyl-substituted cyclopentadienyl ligands were better able to delocalize the electron density away from the metal than the alkyl-substituted analogues. Although Nd(II) and Dy(II) complexes have been isolated with the tris(tert-butyl)cyclopentadienyl ligand, C5H2(CMe3)3 (Cpttt), they were isolated as bis(cyclopentadienyl) metallocenes with a third noncyclopentadienyl ligand: [Cpttt 2Nd(μ-I)K(18-crown-6)]⋅C6H12 and [Cpttt 2Dy(μ-X)K(18-crown-6)] (X = BH4, Br, I).

elements.content: EPR data obtained from previous attempts to make new Y­(II) complexes supported the idea of the importance of silyl-substituted cyclopentadienyl ligands. In contrast to the reduction of Cp′3Y shown in , which gave the crystallographically characterizable anion (Cp′3Y)1–, potassium reductions of Cp3Y (Cp = C5H5) and CpMe 3Y (CpMe = C5H4Me) gave EPR spectra consistent with those of Y­(II), but no crystalline complexes were isolated. The EPR data showed larger hyperfine coupling constants for the solutions generated from Cp3Y and CpMe 3Y, 42.8 and 46.9 G, respectively, compared to the 36.6 G value of the (Cp′3Y)1– product that could be isolated. Reduction of Y­(NR2)3 (R = SiMe3) and Y­(OAr′)3 (OAr′ = OC6H2 t Bu2-2,6-Me-4) also failed to give isolable Y­(II) products and had even larger hyperfine values, 110 and 154 G, respectively. The larger A values were consistent with more electron density on the metal, and this correlated with the difficulty in isolating these products.
elements.clean_text: EPR data obtained from previous attempts to make new Y(II) complexes supported the idea of the importance of silyl-substituted cyclopentadienyl ligands. In contrast to the reduction of Cp'3Y shown in , which gave the crystallographically characterizable anion (Cp'3Y)1-, potassium reductions of Cp3Y (Cp = C5H5) and CpMe 3Y (CpMe = C5H4Me) gave EPR spectra consistent with those of Y(II), but no crystalline complexes were isolated. The EPR data showed larger hyperfine coupling constants for the solutions generated from Cp3Y and CpMe 3Y, 42.8 and 46.9 G, respectively, compared to the 36.6 G value of the (Cp'3Y)1- product that could be isolated. Reduction of Y(NR2)3 (R = SiMe3) and Y(OAr')3 (OAr' = OC6H2  t Bu2-2,6-Me-4) also failed to give isolable Y(II) products and had even larger hyperfine values, 110 and 154 G, respectively. The larger A values were consistent with more electron density on the metal, and this correlated with the difficulty in isolating these products.

elements.content: On this basis, it was not expected that C5H4CMe3 (Cpt) ligands would be good ligands for stabilizing nontraditional Ln­(II) ions. However, the recent discovery that the silylamide ligands, N­(SiMe3)2, can stabilize Sc­(II) and a wide range of Ln­(II) complexes, suggested that the ideas of ligand donor power and Ln­(II) complex stability should be tested further. It was also found that Ln­(II) complexes could be supported with C5Me4H ligands, but that these complexes had unusually long Ln–(ring centroid) distances that could mitigate the effect of the alkyl substituents. To study ring substitution effects further, reductions of Cpt 3Ln were investigated as this Cpt should be sterically similar to the commonly used Cp′ and would allow a direct electronic effect comparison. This study has expanded further the library of ligands that will support unusual Ln­(II) ions and revealed a polymeric structural option that is available.

To study ring substitution effects further, reductions of Cpt 3Ln were investigated as this Cpt should be sterically similar to the commonly used Cp' and would allow a direct electronic effect comparison. This study has expanded further the library of ligands that will support unusual Ln(II) ions and revealed a polymeric structural option that is available.

elements.content: The trivalent Cpt 3Ln­(THF) x (x = 0, 1) complexes used in this study were initially synthesized following the literature procedures reported in 1989–1992 for Ln = Y, Ce, Nd, Dy, and Tm when x = 0 and Ln = La when x = 1. These involved the salt metathesis of LnCl3 with an alkali metal salt of the ligand, MCpt (M = Na, K). Cpt 3La and Cpt 3Ce, prepared in this way from KCpt in this study, provided single crystals, and the complexes were structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction (see Supporting Information) for comparison with Ln­(II) analogues as this is a useful way to evaluate the electron configuration of a divalent lanthanide complex.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis of Trivalent Precursors

The trivalent Cpt 3Ln(THF) x  (x = 0, 1) complexes used in this study were initially synthesized following the literature procedures reported in 1989-1992 for Ln = Y, Ce, Nd, Dy, and Tm when x = 0 and Ln = La when x = 1. These involved the salt metathesis of LnCl3 with an alkali metal salt of the ligand, MCpt (M = Na, K). Cpt 3La and Cpt 3Ce, prepared in this way from KCpt in this study, provided single crystals, and the complexes were structurally characterized by X-ray diffraction (see Supporting Information) for comparison with Ln(II) analogues as this is a useful way to evaluate the electron configuration of a divalent lanthanide complex.

elements.content: Cpt 3La and Cpt 3Ce crystallize in the Pn space group and are isomorphous with each other. However, they are not isomorphous with Cpt 3Nd, the only other complex of this type previously characterized by X-ray crystallography, which crystallizes in the P212121 space group. Cpt 3La and Cpt 3Ce crystallize as monometallic species without any close intermolecular distances. Unfortunately, the data on the lanthanum complex were not of sufficient quality to discuss metrical parameters. Metrical data on Cpt 3Ce and Cpt 3Nd are presented in and compared with those of analogous Cp′3Ln complexes. The average Ln–(Cpt centroid) distances for Cpt 3Ce and Cpt 3Nd, that is, 2.540 and 2.504 Å, respectively, are consistent with the variation in ionic radii. Comparison of each specific Cpt 3Ln to its analogous Cp′3Ln complex shows that the two ligands give similar metal–centroid distances.

The average Ln-(Cpt centroid) distances for Cpt 3Ce and Cpt 3Nd, that is, 2.540 and 2.504 Å, respectively, are consistent with the variation in ionic radii. Comparison of each specific Cpt 3Ln to its analogous Cp'3Ln complex shows that the two ligands give similar metal-centroid distances.

Subsequently, it became of interest to use the lithium salt analogue, LiCpt, in the syntheses of the Cpt 3Ln complexes as it can be synthesized directly from commercially accessible 6,6-dimethylfulvene and methyllithium. Unfortunately, no reaction was observed when LiCpt and LnCl3 were stirred in THF or toluene even at reflux. However, Cpt 3Ln complexes (Ln = La, Ce, Gd, Y) could be isolated in 60–85% yield from the reaction of LiCpt and the triflate complexes, Ln­(OTf)3, in Et2O or THF, followed by reflux in toluene.

elements.content: Reaction of a prechilled purple Et2O solution of Cpt 3Ce (prepared from CeCl3 and KCpt in 80% yield) with potassium graphite at −35 °C in the presence of 18-crown-6 generated a black solution consistent with reduction. After 12 h at −35 °C, the mixture was filtered and the filtrate layered with pentane at −35 °C. After several days, a very small quantity of crystals was obtained along with a large quantity of oily material. The crystals were determined by X-ray crystallography to be the polymeric {[K­(18-crown-6)]­[(μ-Cpt)2CeCpt]} n , 1-Ce ( and ).

Reduction Chemistry: Ce and Gd

Reaction of a prechilled purple Et2O solution of Cpt 3Ce (prepared from CeCl3 and KCpt in 80% yield) with potassium graphite at -35 °C in the presence of 18-crown-6 generated a black solution consistent with reduction. After 12 h at -35 °C, the mixture was filtered and the filtrate layered with pentane at -35 °C. After several days, a very small quantity of crystals was obtained along with a large quantity of oily material. The crystals were determined by X-ray crystallography to be the polymeric {[K(18-crown-6)][(μ-Cpt)2CeCpt]} n , 1-Ce ( and ).

elements.content: In the structure of 1-Ce, each cerium center is surrounded by one terminal η5-Cpt ligand and two bridging μ-η5:η2-Cpt ligands. Each bridging Cpt ligand has two carbon atoms oriented toward the potassium, which is also coordinated by 18-crown-6 and another μ-η5:η2-Cpt ligand on the other side. There is disorder about each cerium center and one of its tert-butyl substituents that prevents detailed analysis of the metrical parameters. Multiple attempts to reproduce this complex have only yielded oily material. Therefore, full characterization of 1-Ce was not feasible, but the structure shows that the Cpt ligand can support Ce­(II). Another polymeric Ln­(II) complex linked by [K­(18-crown-6)]1+ has previously been reported with Cp′ ligands, namely, the Tb­(II) complex­{[K­(18-crown-6)]­[Cp′3Tb]} n .

elements.content: When 1-Ce was first isolated, it was thought that the identification of a Ce­(II) complex with Cpt ligands was only possible because the product was trapped as a polymer. However, an analogous reaction in THF rather than Et2O yielded another dark-colored product which crystallized as the monomeric [K­(18-crown-6)­(THF)2]­[Cpt 3Ce], 2-Ce ( and ). In this case, the coordination sphere of the potassium in the crown ether is filled with two THF molecules rather than two η5:η2-Cpt ligands. The average Ce–(Cpt centroid) distance in 2-Ce is 2.580 Å, which is 0.039 Å longer than the 2.540 Å average in Cpt 3Ce. This difference is similar to the Ce­(III)/Ce­(II) difference of 0.029 Å observed in the previously reported Cp′3Ce/(Cp′3Ce)1– system in which the Ce­(II) ion was assigned a 4f15d1 ground state. The room temperature UV–visible spectrum of 2-Ce is shown in . The absorption at 617 nm (ε = 1400 M–1 cm–1) occurs in a region close to that of [K­(2.2.2-cryptand)]­[Cp′3Ce], 635 (ε = 4700 M–1 cm–1). In addition, the spectrum of 2-Ce shows an additional absorption at 370 nm (1500 M–1 cm–1). The dark color of 2-Ce persisted for several hours at room temperature, but after 24 h, the sample color had faded to yellow.

elements.content: An analogous reaction of Cpt 3Gd with potassium graphite in THF yielded a dark-colored crystallographically characterizable Gd­(II) complex, [K­(18-crown-6)­(THF)2]­[Cpt 3Gd], 2-Gd, which is isomorphous with 2-Ce. The 2.482 Å average Gd–Cpt(centroid) distance in 2-Gd is 0.098 Å smaller than that in 2-Ce, a difference very similar to the 0.099 Å difference in the nine-coordinate ionic radii of Ce­(III) and Gd­(III). The crystal structure of Cpt 3Gd is not available for comparison, but Cp′3Gd has a 2.437 Å Gd–centroid distance, and the value in [K­(2.2.2-cryptand)]­[Cp′3Gd], which was assigned a 4f75d1 configuration, is 2.468 Å. The latter distance is similar to that in 2-Gd. Although the Cpt and Cp′ ligands are different, shows that they have similar metrical parameters in the tris­(cyclopentadienyl) complexes.

The 2.482 Å average Gd-Cpt(centroid) distance in 2-Gd is 0.098 Å smaller than that in 2-Ce, a difference very similar to the 0.099 Å difference in the nine-coordinate ionic radii of Ce(III) and Gd(III). The crystal structure of Cpt 3Gd is not available for comparison, but Cp'3Gd has a 2.437 Å Gd-centroid distance, and the value in [K(2.2.2-cryptand)][Cp'3Gd], which was assigned a 4f75d1 configuration, is 2.468 Å. The latter distance is similar to that in 2-Gd. Although the Cpt and Cp' ligands are different,  shows that they have similar metrical parameters in the tris(cyclopentadienyl) complexes.

elements.content: The UV–visible spectrum of 2-Gd at room temperature is shown in . The absorptions [nm (ε, M–1 cm–1)] at 380 (2100), 525 (1300), and 686 (700) can be compared to those reported for [K­(2.2.2-cryptand)]­[Cp′3Gd], 282 (5700), 430 (4400), and 630 (1400 shoulder). As for 2-Ce, the color of 2-Gd persisted for several hours at room temperature but not for a full day. The EPR spectrum of 2-Gd (see the Supporting Information) has a featureless signal with g = 1.88 similar to the spectra of other Gd­(II) species.

elements.content: In one of the attempts to resynthesize 1-Ce, the dark Et2O solution was layered with hexanes instead of pentane. After several months, a small quantity of crystals was obtained. The crystals were determined by X-ray crystallography to be the bimetallic mixed-valence complex, [K­(18-crown-6)]­[(μ-Cpt)­CeCpt 2]2, 3-Ce (). The structure of 3-Ce is similar to that of 1-Ce in that it contains terminal and bridging cyclopentadienyl ligands, but in this case, there are two terminal η5-Cpt ligands and one μ-η5:η2-Cpt ligand per cerium.

elements.content: Lappert and co-workers previously reported a mixed-valent cerium complex with Cp″, that is, [K­(18-crown-6)]­[Cp″3Ce]·[Cp″3Ce]. In that complex, the two cerium centers are crystallographically distinguishable with average ring centroid distances of 2.57 Å [assigned to Ce­(III)] and 2.60 Å [assigned to Ce­(II)]. In 3-Ce, the metal centers are indistinguishable because the molecule sits on an inversion center with the potassium cation in the center. The 2.555 Å average Ce–(Cpt centroid) distance is 0.015 Å longer than Cpt 3Ce and 0.025 shorter than that in 2-Ce. Multiple attempts to reproduce 3-Ce have only yielded oily material.

elements.content: Attempts to reduce Cpt 3Ln complexes of La, Nd, Ho, and Y with K in the presence of 18-crown-6 or 2.2.2-cryptand did not give isolable crystalline material, but color changes to form dark solutions were observed that were consistent with color changes in . In the case of the 99.99% naturally abundant 139La (I = 7/2), EPR spectroscopy on the dark solution revealed an isotropic eight-line pattern at room temperature (g iso = 1.959, A iso = 204 G), and an axial signal was observed from a spectrum obtained at 77 K (g ∥ = 1.9950, g ⊥ = 1.9410, A ∥ = 197 G, A ⊥ = 208 G) (). With the 100% naturally abundant 89Y (I = 1/2), the EPR spectrum of the dark solution contained an isotropic two-line pattern at room temperature (g iso = 1.988, A = 51.0 G) and an axial signal at 77 K (g ∥ = 2.0020, g ⊥ = 1.9840, A ∥ = 47.4 G, A ⊥ = 51.1 G) (). The coupling constants (A) of these species follow the pattern previously observed for the reductions of other cyclopentadienyl complexes, as shown in .
elements.clean_text:
Reduction Chemistry: La, Nd, Ho, and Y

Attempts to reduce Cpt 3Ln complexes of La, Nd, Ho, and Y with K in the presence of 18-crown-6 or 2.2.2-cryptand did not give isolable crystalline material, but color changes to form dark solutions were observed that were consistent with color changes in . In the case of the 99.99% naturally abundant 139La (I = 7/2), EPR spectroscopy on the dark solution revealed an isotropic eight-line pattern at room temperature (g iso = 1.959, A iso = 204 G), and an axial signal was observed from a spectrum obtained at 77 K (g ∥ = 1.9950, g ⊥ = 1.9410, A ∥ = 197 G, A ⊥ = 208 G) (). With the 100% naturally abundant 89Y (I = 1/2), the EPR spectrum of the dark solution contained an isotropic two-line pattern at room temperature (g iso = 1.988, A = 51.0 G) and an axial signal at 77 K (g ∥ = 2.0020, g ⊥ = 1.9840, A ∥ = 47.4 G, A ⊥ = 51.1 G) (). The coupling constants (A) of these species follow the pattern previously observed for the reductions of other cyclopentadienyl complexes, as shown in .

Most reductions of Cpt 3Ln conducted with potassium graphite in the presence of 2.2.2-cryptand, rather than the 18-crown-6 reactions described above, did not yield products that provided X-ray crystal data. However, the reaction of Cpt 3Dy with KC8 in the presence of 2.2.2-cryptand in Et2O at −15 °C generated a dark-colored solution from which a crystalline sample of the mixed-valent complex, [K­(2.2.2-cryptand)]­[Cpt 3Dy]2, 4-Dy (), was isolated. Similar to 3-Ce, the dysprosium centers are indistinguishable due to an inversion center. The 2.440 Å average Dy–(Cpt ring centroid) distance in 3-Dy is similar to the 2.443 Å analogue in [K­(2.2.2-cryptand)]­[Cp′3Dy].

elements.content: In summary, the C5H4CMe3, Cpt, ligand should be added to the list of ancillary ligands that allow isolation of crystallographically characterizable Ln­(II) ions surrounded by three cyclopentadienyl ligands. The hyperfine coupling constants in the EPR spectra of the products of the reduction of Cpt 3Ln for Ln = Y and La are consistent with the expected stronger donor power of the Cpt ligands compared to Cp′. Hence, although isolation of the silyl analogues, (Cp′3Ln)1–, is more facile with both 18-crown-6 and 2.2.2-cryptand as potassium chelators, (Cpt 3Ln)1– complexes can be isolated with 18-crown-6 for both large and intermediate-sized lanthanides, Ce and Gd, respectively. The metrical parameters and UV–vis spectra are consistent with 4fn5d1 electron configurations as previously found for these ions.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, the C5H4CMe3, Cpt, ligand should be added to the list of ancillary ligands that allow isolation of crystallographically characterizable Ln(II) ions surrounded by three cyclopentadienyl ligands. The hyperfine coupling constants in the EPR spectra of the products of the reduction of Cpt 3Ln for Ln = Y and La are consistent with the expected stronger donor power of the Cpt ligands compared to Cp'. Hence, although isolation of the silyl analogues, (Cp'3Ln)1-, is more facile with both 18-crown-6 and 2.2.2-cryptand as potassium chelators, (Cpt 3Ln)1- complexes can be isolated with 18-crown-6 for both large and intermediate-sized lanthanides, Ce and Gd, respectively. The metrical parameters and UV-vis spectra are consistent with 4fn5d1 electron configurations as previously found for these ions.

elements.content: The Cpt ligand also allows isolation of the polymeric Ln­(II) complex, {[K­(18-crown-6)]­[(μ-Cpt)2CeCpt]} n , that demonstrates a new structural motif for the +2 oxidation states species with a {(η5:η2-Cpt)­[K­(18-crown-6)]­(η5:η2-Cpt)}1– linking unit. Trapping Ln­(II) ions in a polymer like this could be a useful method to isolate highly reactive ions if general routes to such species can be developed. The isolation of the mixed-valent complexes {[K­(18-crown)-6]­[(μ-Cpt)­CeCpt 2]2} n and [K­(2.2.2-cryptand)]­[Cpt 3Dy]2 demonstrates that such Ln­(III)/Ln­(II) complexes are accessible beyond the single Cp″ cerium example in the literature. Overall, these results demonstrate that a wider variety of ligands will support Ln­(II) ions than previously anticipated. The data also emphasize the importance of the selection of solvent and potassium chelate in generating pure crystallographically characterizable Ln­(II) complexes.

Trapping Ln(II) ions in a polymer like this could be a useful method to isolate highly reactive ions if general routes to such species can be developed. The isolation of the mixed-valent complexes {[K(18-crown)-6][(μ-Cpt)CeCpt 2]2} n  and [K(2.2.2-cryptand)][Cpt 3Dy]2 demonstrates that such Ln(III)/Ln(II) complexes are accessible beyond the single Cp" cerium example in the literature. Overall, these results demonstrate that a wider variety of ligands will support Ln(II) ions than previously anticipated. The data also emphasize the importance of the selection of solvent and potassium chelate in generating pure crystallographically characterizable Ln(II) complexes.

elements.content: All manipulations and syntheses described below were conducted with the rigorous exclusion of air and water using standard Schlenk line and glovebox techniques under an argon atmosphere. Solvents were sparged with ultra-high-pressure argon and dried by passage through columns containing Q-5 and molecular sieves prior to use. Deuterated NMR solvents were dried over NaK alloy, degassed by three freeze–pump–thaw cycles, and vacuum transferred before use. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker DR400, GN500, or CRYO500 MHz spectrometers at 298 K unless otherwise stated and referenced internally to residual protio-solvent resonances. EPR spectra were collected using a Bruker EMX spectrometer equipped with an ER041XG microwave bridge calibrated with DPPH. EPR simulations were performed as least-squares fits of the experimental spectra via the Nelder/Mead downhill simplex method using EasySpin. Electronic absorption spectra were collected using a Varian Cary 50 Scan UV–vis spectrophotometer in THF at 298 K. Infrared (IR) measurements were taken as compressed solids on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iD5 spectrophotometer with an iD5 ATR attachment. Elemental analyses were conducted on a PerkinElmer 2400 Series II CHNS elemental analyzer. A mixture of isomers of tert-butylcyclopentadiene (HCpt) was purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and was used without further purification. Ce­(OTf)3 (OTf = CF3SO3) was purchased from Strem Chemicals and dried at 220 °C at 10–4 Torr for 2 days and then pulverized and dried at 220 °C at 10–5 Torr for 2 days. Ln­(OTf)3 (Ln = La, Gd, Nd, Ho, Y) was purchased from Strem Chemicals and dried at 200 °C at 10–5 Torr for 2 days. 6,6-Dimethylfulvene was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. 2.2.2-Cryptand (crypt) was purchased from Merck and dried under reduced pressure before use. 18-Crown-6 was purchased from Aldrich and sublimed before use. KCpt, Cpt 3Dy, anhydrous LnCl3 (Ln = Y, Gd, Dy), KC8, and LiCpt were prepared according to the literature procedures.

Experimental Details

All manipulations and syntheses described below were conducted with the rigorous exclusion of air and water using standard Schlenk line and glovebox techniques under an argon atmosphere. Solvents were sparged with ultra-high-pressure argon and dried by passage through columns containing Q-5 and molecular sieves prior to use. Deuterated NMR solvents were dried over NaK alloy, degassed by three freeze-pump-thaw cycles, and vacuum transferred before use. 1H NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker DR400, GN500, or CRYO500 MHz spectrometers at 298 K unless otherwise stated and referenced internally to residual protio-solvent resonances. EPR spectra were collected using a Bruker EMX spectrometer equipped with an ER041XG microwave bridge calibrated with DPPH. EPR simulations were performed as least-squares fits of the experimental spectra via the Nelder/Mead downhill simplex method using EasySpin. Electronic absorption spectra were collected using a Varian Cary 50 Scan UV-vis spectrophotometer in THF at 298 K. Infrared (IR) measurements were taken as compressed solids on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iD5 spectrophotometer with an iD5 ATR attachment. Elemental analyses were conducted on a PerkinElmer 2400 Series II CHNS elemental analyzer. A mixture of isomers of tert-butylcyclopentadiene (HCpt) was purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and was used without further purification. Ce(OTf)3 (OTf = CF3SO3) was purchased from Strem Chemicals and dried at 220 °C at 10-4 Torr for 2 days and then pulverized and dried at 220 °C at 10-5 Torr for 2 days. Ln(OTf)3 (Ln = La, Gd, Nd, Ho, Y) was purchased from Strem Chemicals and dried at 200 °C at 10-5 Torr for 2 days. 6,6-Dimethylfulvene was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and used without further purification. 2.2.2-Cryptand (crypt) was purchased from Merck and dried under reduced pressure before use. 18-Crown-6 was purchased from Aldrich and sublimed before use. KCpt, Cpt 3Dy, anhydrous LnCl3 (Ln = Y, Gd, Dy), KC8, and LiCpt  were prepared according to the literature procedures.

elements.content: Following a previous report on the synthesis of Cpt 3Ce, CeCl3 (250 mg, 1.01 mmol) and KCpt (507 mg, 3.16 mmol) were reacted in Et2O (15 mL) in a glovebox to yield Cpt 3Ce (409 mg, 80%). Blue single crystals of (C5H4CMe3)3Ce suitable for X-ray diffraction were grown from a concentrated solution of Et2O at −30 °C. The 1H NMR spectrum (C6D6) of the crystals matched the literature value.
elements.clean_text:
Cpt 3Ce from CeCl3 and KCpt 

Following a previous report on the synthesis of Cpt 3Ce, CeCl3 (250 mg, 1.01 mmol) and KCpt (507 mg, 3.16 mmol) were reacted in Et2O (15 mL) in a glovebox to yield Cpt 3Ce (409 mg, 80%). Blue single crystals of (C5H4CMe3)3Ce suitable for X-ray diffraction were grown from a concentrated solution of Et2O at -30 °C. The 1H NMR spectrum (C6D6) of the crystals matched the literature value.

elements.content: In a glovebox, a Schlenk flask was charged with Ce­(OTf)3 (200 mg, 0.34 mmol), LiCpt (134 mg, 1.05 mmol), and Et2O (30 mL). The mixture was allowed to stir for 20 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and toluene (30 mL) was added to the flask. The flask was sealed, brought out of the glovebox, and the solution was refluxed under reduced pressure for 8 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and the flask was returned to the glovebox. The product was extracted using hexanes, and a white precipitate was removed via centrifugation. The extract was filtered, and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure to yield (C5H4CMe3)3Ce (136 mg, 79%) as confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy.

elements.content: Following a previous report on the synthesis of Cpt 3La­(THF), THF (30 mL) was added in a glovebox to a Schlenk flask charged with LaCl3 (100 mg, 0.41 mmol) to form a white slurry. An opaque solid of KCpt (198 mg, 1.24 mmol) was added to the slurry, and the cloudy brown mixture was allowed to stir for 20 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and toluene (30 mL) was added to the flask. The flask was sealed, brought out of the glovebox, and refluxed under reduced pressure for 24 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and the flask was returned to the glovebox. The product was extracted using hexanes, and the white precipitate was removed via centrifugation. The extract was filtered, and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure to yield (C5H4CMe3)3La (140 mg, 68%). 1H NMR analysis of the final product indicated no presence of THF. 1H NMR (C6D6): δ 6.10 (t, 6H, C5 H 4CMe3), 6.04 (t, 6H, C5 H 4CMe3), 1.19 (s, 27H, C5H4CMe 3). Colorless single crystals of (C5H4CMe3)3La suitable for X-ray diffraction were grown from a concentrated solution of Et2O at −30 °C.

elements.content: In a glovebox, LiCpt (100 mg, 0.78 mmol) was added to a solution of La­(OTf)3 (150 mg, 0.26 mmol) in THF (10 mL). The solution was stirred for 20 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, toluene (20 mL) was added to the flask, and the solution was refluxed under reduced pressure. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and the product was extracted using hexanes. Solvent was removed under vacuum to afford a yellow oil. The oil was cooled to −10 °C overnight to form tacky yellow solids of Cpt 3La identified by 1H NMR spectroscopy.

elements.content: In a glovebox, Cpt 3Ce (10 mg, 0.020 mmol) and 18-crown-6 (5.2 mg, 0.020 mmol) were dissolved in Et2O (3 mL) and cooled to −35 °C. KC8 (3 mg, 0.020 mmol) was added to the purple mixture to produce a color change to black. Black insoluble material, presumably graphite, was removed by filtration to yield a black solution. Layer diffusion of the dark solution with pentane at −35 °C yielded black crystals of {[K­(18-crown-6)]­[(μ-Cpt)2CeCpt]} n , 1-Ce, suitable for X-ray diffraction. The yield of this reaction was low as only several small crystals were obtained.

cln_elements.content:
Following a previous report on the synthesis of Cpt 3Ce, CeCl3 (250 mg, 1.01 mmol) and KCpt (507 mg, 3.16 mmol) were reacted in Et2O (15 mL) in a glovebox to yield Cpt 3Ce (409 mg, 80%). Blue single crystals of (C5H4CMe3)3Ce suitable for X-ray diffraction were grown from a concentrated solution of Et2O at −30 °C. The 1H NMR spectrum (C6D6) of the crystals matched the literature value.

Cp<sup>t</sup> <sub>3</sub>Ce from Ce­(OTf)<sub>3</sub> and LiCp<sup>t</sup>

In a glovebox, a Schlenk flask was charged with Ce­(OTf)3 (200 mg, 0.34 mmol), LiCpt (134 mg, 1.05 mmol), and Et2O (30 mL). The mixture was allowed to stir for 20 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and toluene (30 mL) was added to the flask. The flask was sealed, brought out of the glovebox, and the solution was refluxed under reduced pressure for 8 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and the flask was returned to the glovebox. The product was extracted using hexanes, and a white precipitate was removed via centrifugation. The extract was filtered, and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure to yield (C5H4CMe3)3Ce (136 mg, 79%) as confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy.

Cp<sup>t</sup> <sub>3</sub>La from LaCl<sub>3</sub> and KCp<sup>t</sup>

Following a previous report on the synthesis of Cpt 3La­(THF), THF (30 mL) was added in a glovebox to a Schlenk flask charged with LaCl3 (100 mg, 0.41 mmol) to form a white slurry. An opaque solid of KCpt (198 mg, 1.24 mmol) was added to the slurry, and the cloudy brown mixture was allowed to stir for 20 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and toluene (30 mL) was added to the flask. The flask was sealed, brought out of the glovebox, and refluxed under reduced pressure for 24 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and the flask was returned to the glovebox. The product was extracted using hexanes, and the white precipitate was removed via centrifugation. The extract was filtered, and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure to yield (C5H4CMe3)3La (140 mg, 68%). 1H NMR analysis of the final product indicated no presence of THF. 1H NMR (C6D6): δ 6.10 (t, 6H, C5 H 4CMe3), 6.04 (t, 6H, C5 H 4CMe3), 1.19 (s, 27H, C5H4CMe 3). Colorless single crystals of (C5H4CMe3)3La suitable for X-ray diffraction were grown from a concentrated solution of Et2O at −30 °C.

Cp<sup>t</sup> <sub>3</sub>La from La­(OTf)<sub>3</sub> and LiCp<sup>t</sup>

In a glovebox, LiCpt (100 mg, 0.78 mmol) was added to a solution of La­(OTf)3 (150 mg, 0.26 mmol) in THF (10 mL). The solution was stirred for 20 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, toluene (20 mL) was added to the flask, and the solution was refluxed under reduced pressure. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and the product was extracted using hexanes. Solvent was removed under vacuum to afford a yellow oil. The oil was cooled to −10 °C overnight to form tacky yellow solids of Cpt 3La identified by 1H NMR spectroscopy.

Cp<sup>t</sup> <sub>3</sub>Y from Y­(OTf)<sub>3</sub> and LiCp<sup>t</sup>

Similar to the preparation of Cpt 3La from La­(OTf)3 and LiCpt, LiCpt (161 mg, 1.25 mmol) was added to a solution of Y­(OTf)3 (220 mg, 0.410 mmol) in THF (15 mL). After extraction of the product from hexanes, the solvent was removed under vacuum to afford a yellow oil of Cpt 3Y (129 mg, 69%) which was identified by 1H NMR spectroscopy.

{[K­(18-Crown-6)]­[(μ-Cp<sup>t</sup>)<sub>2</sub>CeCp<sup>t</sup>]}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>, <bold>1-Ce</bold>

In a glovebox, Cpt 3Ce (10 mg, 0.020 mmol) and 18-crown-6 (5.2 mg, 0.020 mmol) were dissolved in Et2O (3 mL) and cooled to −35 °C. KC8 (3 mg, 0.020 mmol) was added to the purple mixture to produce a color change to black. Black insoluble material, presumably graphite, was removed by filtration to yield a black solution. Layer diffusion of the dark solution with pentane at −35 °C yielded black crystals of {[K­(18-crown-6)]­[(μ-Cpt)2CeCpt]} n , 1-Ce, suitable for X-ray diffraction. The yield of this reaction was low as only several small crystals were obtained.

[K­(18-Crown-6)­(THF)<sub>2</sub>]­[Cp<sup>t</sup> <sub>3</sub>Ce], <bold>2-Ce</bold>

Similar to the preparation of 1-Ce except with THF (3 mL) rather than Et2O as the solvent, the reduction of Cpt 3Ce (68 mg, 0.14 mmol) in the presence of 18-crown-6 (36 mg, 0.14 mmol) using KC8 (20 mg, 0.13 mmol) yielded black single crystals of [K­(18-crown-6)­(THF)2]­[Cpt 3Ce], 2-Ce (34 mg, 27%), suitable for X-ray diffraction from THF/hexane layer diffusion at −35 °C. IR: 2951m, 2895m, 2857m, 1472w, 1457w, 1351m, 1281w, 1249w, 1199w, 1108s, 1042w, 962m, 917w, 837w, 807w, 738m, 702w, 668w cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C51H87O9KCe: C, 59.85; H, 8.57. Found: C, 54.75; H, 7.82. The found C/H ratio, C51H87, is consistent with the formula and suggests incomplete combustion.

[K­(18-Crown-6)­(THF)<sub>2</sub>]­[Cp<sup>t</sup> <sub>3</sub>Gd], <bold>2-Gd</bold>

Similar to the preparation of 2-Ce, the reduction of Cpt 3Gd [36 mg, 0.069 mmol, prepared from Gd­(OTf)3 and LiCpt] in the presence of 18-crown-6 (19 mg, 0.073 mmol) using KC8 (10 mg, 0.074 mmol) yielded black single crystals of [K­(18-crown-6)­(THF)2]­[Cpt 3Gd], 2-Gd (33 mg, 58%), suitable for X-ray diffraction from THF/hexane layer diffusion at −35 °C. IR: 2947m, 2895m, 2861m, 1471w, 1456w, 1351m, 1281w, 1249w, 1200w, 1106s, 1041w, 962m, 917w,837w, 802w, 748m, 679w cm–1. Anal. Calcd for C51H87O9KGd: C, 58.87; H, 8.43. Found: C, 55.03; H, 7.90. Similar to 2-Ce, the found C/H ratio, C51H87.24, is consistent with the formula and suggests incomplete combustion.

[K­(18-Crown-6)]­[(μ-Cp<sup>t</sup>)­CeCp<sup>t</sup> <sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub>, <bold>3-Ce</bold>

In a glovebox, Cpt 3Ce (39 mg, 0.077 mmol), 18-crown-6 (20 mg, 0.076 mmol), and KC8 (11 mg, 0.081 mmol) were dissolved in chilled Et2O (2 mL) and cooled to −35 °C. Black insoluble material, presumably graphite, was removed by filtration to yield a black solution. Layer diffusion of the dark solution with hexanes at −35 °C yielded black crystals of [K­(18-crown-6)]­[(μ-Cpt)­CeCpt 2]2, 3-Ce, suitable for X-ray diffraction. The yield of this reaction was low as only several small crystals were obtained.

[K­(2.2.2-Cryptand)]­[Cp<sup>t</sup> <sub>3</sub>Dy]<sub>2</sub>, <bold>4-Dy</bold>

In a glovebox, Cpt 3Dy (13 mg, 0.025 mmol, prepared from DyCl3 and KCpt) and 2.2.2-cryptand (10 mg, 0.026 mmol) were dissolved in Et2O (2 mL) and cooled to −15 °C. KC8 (7.7 mg, 0.057 mmol) was added to the yellow mixture to produce a color change to dark. The graphite was filtered using a chilled filter pipet. The filtrate immediately solidified upon contact with a chilled collection vial. Although the yield of this reaction was low and only several small crystals were obtained, they were suitable for X-ray diffraction and were identified as 4-Dy.

Reduction of Cp<sup>t</sup> <sub>3</sub>La

In a glovebox, Cpt 3La (16 mg, 0.032 mmol) and 2.2.2-cryptand (12 mg, 0.032 mmol) were dissolved in Et2O (3 mL) and cooled to −35 °C. KC8 (7.7 mg, 0.057 mmol) was added to the colorless mixture to produce a color change to dark. Black insoluble material, presumably graphite, was removed by filtration to yield a dark maroon solution. The dark color of the solution persisted after a few days at low temperature (−35 °C).

Cpt 3Ce from CeCl3 and KCpt 

Following a previous report on the synthesis of Cpt 3Ce, CeCl3 (250 mg, 1.01 mmol) and KCpt (507 mg, 3.16 mmol) were reacted in Et2O (15 mL) in a glovebox to yield Cpt 3Ce (409 mg, 80%). Blue single crystals of (C5H4CMe3)3Ce suitable for X-ray diffraction were grown from a concentrated solution of Et2O at -30 °C. The 1H NMR spectrum (C6D6) of the crystals matched the literature value.

In a glovebox, a Schlenk flask was charged with Ce(OTf)3 (200 mg, 0.34 mmol), LiCpt (134 mg, 1.05 mmol), and Et2O (30 mL). The mixture was allowed to stir for 20 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and toluene (30 mL) was added to the flask. The flask was sealed, brought out of the glovebox, and the solution was refluxed under reduced pressure for 8 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and the flask was returned to the glovebox. The product was extracted using hexanes, and a white precipitate was removed via centrifugation. The extract was filtered, and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure to yield (C5H4CMe3)3Ce (136 mg, 79%) as confirmed by 1H NMR spectroscopy. 

Cpt 3La from LaCl3 and KCpt 

Following a previous report on the synthesis of Cpt 3La(THF), THF (30 mL) was added in a glovebox to a Schlenk flask charged with LaCl3 (100 mg, 0.41 mmol) to form a white slurry. An opaque solid of KCpt (198 mg, 1.24 mmol) was added to the slurry, and the cloudy brown mixture was allowed to stir for 20 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and toluene (30 mL) was added to the flask. The flask was sealed, brought out of the glovebox, and refluxed under reduced pressure for 24 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and the flask was returned to the glovebox. The product was extracted using hexanes, and the white precipitate was removed via centrifugation. Colorless single crystals of (C5H4CMe3)3La suitable for X-ray diffraction were grown from a concentrated solution of Et2O at -30 °C.

In a glovebox, LiCpt (100 mg, 0.78 mmol) was added to a solution of La(OTf)3 (150 mg, 0.26 mmol) in THF (10 mL). The solution was stirred for 20 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum, toluene (20 mL) was added to the flask, and the solution was refluxed under reduced pressure. The oil was cooled to -10 °C overnight to form tacky yellow solids of Cpt 3La identified by 1H NMR spectroscopy.

Cpt 3Y from Y(OTf)3 and LiCpt 

Similar to the preparation of Cpt 3La from La(OTf)3 and LiCpt, LiCpt (161 mg, 1.25 mmol) was added to a solution of Y(OTf)3 (220 mg, 0.410 mmol) in THF (15 mL). After extraction of the product from hexanes, the solvent was removed under vacuum to afford a yellow oil of Cpt 3Y (129 mg, 69%) which was identified by 1H NMR spectroscopy. 

{[K(18-Crown-6)][(μ-Cpt)2CeCpt]} n , 1-Ce 

In a glovebox, Cpt 3Ce (10 mg, 0.020 mmol) and 18-crown-6 (5.2 mg, 0.020 mmol) were dissolved in Et2O (3 mL) and cooled to -35 °C. KC8 (3 mg, 0.020 mmol) was added to the purple mixture to produce a color change to black. Black insoluble material, presumably graphite, was removed by filtration to yield a black solution. Layer diffusion of the dark solution with pentane at -35 °C yielded black crystals of {[K(18-crown-6)][(μ-Cpt)2CeCpt]} n , 1-Ce, suitable for X-ray diffraction. The yield of this reaction was low as only several small crystals were obtained.

[K(18-Crown-6)(THF)2][Cpt 3Ce], 2-Ce 

Similar to the preparation of 1-Ce except with THF (3 mL) rather than Et2O as the solvent, the reduction of Cpt 3Ce (68 mg, 0.14 mmol) in the presence of 18-crown-6 (36 mg, 0.14 mmol) using KC8 (20 mg, 0.13 mmol) yielded black single crystals of [K(18-crown-6)(THF)2][Cpt 3Ce], 2-Ce (34 mg, 27%), suitable for X-ray diffraction from THF/hexane layer diffusion at -35 °C. IR: 2951m, 2895m, 2857m, 1472w, 1457w, 1351m, 1281w, 1249w, 1199w, 1108s, 1042w, 962m, 917w, 837w, 807w, 738m, 702w, 668w cm-1. Anal. Calcd for C51H87O9KCe: C, 59.85; H, 8.57. Found: C, 54.75; H, 7.82. The found C/H ratio, C51H87, is consistent with the formula and suggests incomplete combustion. 

[K(18-Crown-6)(THF)2][Cpt 3Gd], 2-Gd 

Similar to the preparation of 2-Ce, the reduction of Cpt 3Gd [36 mg, 0.069 mmol, prepared from Gd(OTf)3 and LiCpt] in the presence of 18-crown-6 (19 mg, 0.073 mmol) using KC8 (10 mg, 0.074 mmol) yielded black single crystals of [K(18-crown-6)(THF)2][Cpt 3Gd], 2-Gd (33 mg, 58%), suitable for X-ray diffraction from THF/hexane layer diffusion at -35 °C. IR: 2947m, 2895m, 2861m, 1471w, 1456w, 1351m, 1281w, 1249w, 1200w, 1106s, 1041w, 962m, 917w,837w, 802w, 748m, 679w cm-1. Anal. Calcd for C51H87O9KGd: C, 58.87; H, 8.43. Found: C, 55.03; H, 7.90. Similar to 2-Ce, the found C/H ratio, C51H87.24, is consistent with the formula and suggests incomplete combustion. 

[K(18-Crown-6)][(μ-Cpt)CeCpt 2]2, 3-Ce 

In a glovebox, Cpt 3Ce (39 mg, 0.077 mmol), 18-crown-6 (20 mg, 0.076 mmol), and KC8 (11 mg, 0.081 mmol) were dissolved in chilled Et2O (2 mL) and cooled to -35 °C. Black insoluble material, presumably graphite, was removed by filtration to yield a black solution. Layer diffusion of the dark solution with hexanes at -35 °C yielded black crystals of [K(18-crown-6)][(μ-Cpt)CeCpt 2]2, 3-Ce, suitable for X-ray diffraction. The yield of this reaction was low as only several small crystals were obtained.

[K(2.2.2-Cryptand)][Cpt 3Dy]2, 4-Dy 

In a glovebox, Cpt 3Dy (13 mg, 0.025 mmol, prepared from DyCl3 and KCpt) and 2.2.2-cryptand (10 mg, 0.026 mmol) were dissolved in Et2O (2 mL) and cooled to -15 °C. KC8 (7.7 mg, 0.057 mmol) was added to the yellow mixture to produce a color change to dark. The graphite was filtered using a chilled filter pipet. The filtrate immediately solidified upon contact with a chilled collection vial. Although the yield of this reaction was low and only several small crystals were obtained, they were suitable for X-ray diffraction and were identified as 4-Dy.

Reduction of Cpt 3La

In a glovebox, Cpt 3La (16 mg, 0.032 mmol) and 2.2.2-cryptand (12 mg, 0.032 mmol) were dissolved in Et2O (3 mL) and cooled to -35 °C. KC8 (7.7 mg, 0.057 mmol) was added to the colorless mixture to produce a color change to dark. Black insoluble material, presumably graphite, was removed by filtration to yield a dark maroon solution. The dark color of the solution persisted after a few days at low temperature (-35 °C).
